Creole_word: adjasú, akálúbúka, atjawá, bëgogó mbéti, kökö́ni

Definition: to rock or swing back and forth
manner of being, living or doing
mark or scar where a knife has cut
to twist cotton or sisal into thread
to make firm in the ground
conjunction used at beginning of clause to indicate another step in the narrative
to leave a smarting pain (e.g. alagisa jasa mi)
amulet used to ward off thieves
white clay used for religious purposes
pod of palm fruit (after it breaks open, it is often used as large dustpan)
plant used for medicine and obeah
long pole for pushing boat through rapids
log put across creek for crossing
to be protected against black magic
your sister-in-law’s husband or your brother-in-law’s wife
sweet food made with rice, peanuts and sugar
leaves or vine for poisoning fish
aki o}"}expression used at end of sentence to soften speech: ko aki o}
a ride with someone who was already going
woman who has just given birth
long narrow item (e.g. hand of a clock, pencil)
to play an instrument or game
large canvas or plastic sheet to protect
palm branches used for thatching roof
to slide something to one side
to spread a piece of news indiscriminately
a straight stretch of river upriver from Duwata where the current is especially strong
the street in Paramaribo known as Saramacca-straat, where Saramaccans buy most of their supplies and where they take a truck to the interior
small item of which there are many (e.g. bead, candy, pill)
band tied around waist after giving birth
spirit that possesses one when certain trees are felled or damaged
common response used to show that one is listening
expression that indicates a) the end of a conversation b) the beginning of a new topic c) a return to a former topic that has been interrupted
term of address (usually for brother-in-law or sister-in-law)
address for father, father's brother, or father in law
something made skillfully with your hands, e. g.wood-carving, embroidery, decorations on cassava bread
to sew, carve, or do handcraft
to cut off from its stalk (e.g. maripa fruit)
circle made from palm leaves or white clay for ritualistic purposes
to advance by natural mode of locomotion (walk, slither, ride, etc.)
to watch someone with the intention of catching him/her at something
